Situation1: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today.
Story: I pulled my taxi to the curb just as the two travelers waved me down, their arms full of heavy suitcases. They looked exhausted, and I could see the relief in their faces when I stepped out to help. “Can you help us with the bags? We’ll split the fare,” one of them said, already opening the trunk. I glanced at the dashboard clock—ten minutes until my weekly meditation group began. As a Buddhist, I promised myself to never miss these sessions, to practice mindfulness and nurture my inner peace. But as a taxi driver, I’m expected to be professional, helpful, and never turn away a fare, especially when people are in need. My hands gripped the handle of the suitcase, my mind torn between the duty to my passengers and the commitment to my spiritual practice. The weight of their luggage seemed lighter than the heaviness in my chest as I stood there, caught between the world’s demands and my own search for stillness.
